The linear model in statistics can be summarized with the equation outcome = (model) + error.
Variance measures the variability of a single variable.
Covariance measures how two variables vary with each other.
Covariance measures the variability of a single variable.
Variance measures how two variables vary with each other.
A positive covariance means that as one variable deviates from the mean, the other variable deviates in the same direction.
A negative covariance means that as one variable deviates from the mean, the other variable deviates in the opposite direction.
A negative covariance means that as one variable deviates from the mean, the other variable deviates in the same direction.
A positive covariance means that as one variable deviates from the mean, the other variable deviates in the opposite direction.
The covariance value depends on measurement scale.
The covariance value is independent of measurement scale.
The Pearson correlation depends on measurement scale.
The Pearson correlation value is independent of measurement scale.
Pearson correlation coefficient values range between -1 and 1.
Pearson correlation coefficient values range between negative infinity and positive infinity.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to zero mean variables have a weak relationship with each other.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to zero mean variables have a strong relationship with each other.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to one indicate a strong positive relationship. As one variable increases the other variable increases by a proportionate amount.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to one indicate a strong positive relationship. As one variable increases the other variable decreases by a proportionate amount.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to one indicate a strong negative relationship. As one variable increases the other variable decreases by a proportionate amount.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to negative one indicate a strong negative relationship. As one variable increases the other variable decreases by a proportionate amount.
Pearson correlation coefficient values close to negative one indicate a strong positive relationship. As one variable increases the other variable increases by a proportionate amount.
The p-values for correlation coefficients are affected by sample size.
The p-values for correlation coefficients are not affected by sample size.
Spearman's rho is the nonparametric equivalent for Pearson's correlation coefficient.
There is no nonparametric equivalent for Pearson's r.

Pearson's correlation coefficient are effect sizes.
Cohen's d is the effect size for a Pearson's correlation.
We can square Pearson's r to get the proportion of shared variance.
The coefficient of determination is equal to r squared.
The value for Pearson's r gives us the proportion of shared variance.
